title: Refactor Variable Names
description:
Refactor code with poor variable names to follow Python naming conventions.

The code works but violates naming conventions:
- Single letter variables (x, y, z)
- Unclear abbreviations
- Wrong case (camelCase instead of snake_case)
- No descriptive names

Refactor all variable names to be clear and follow PEP 8.

The program calculates a student's final grade.
starterCode:
# Poor variable names - refactor these!
x = 85
y = 90
z = 78
a = 92

t = x + y + z + a
avg = t / 4

if avg >= 90:
    g = "A"
elif avg >= 80:
    g = "B"
elif avg >= 70:
    g = "C"
else:
    g = "F"

print(f"Grade: {g}")
solution:
# Refactored with clear, descriptive names
homework_score = 85
quiz_score = 90
midterm_score = 78
final_exam_score = 92

total_points = homework_score + quiz_score + midterm_score + final_exam_score
average_score = total_points / 4

if average_score >= 90:
    letter_grade = "A"
elif average_score >= 80:
    letter_grade = "B"
elif average_score >= 70:
    letter_grade = "C"
else:
    letter_grade = "F"

print(f"Grade: {letter_grade}")
hints: Replace single letters with descriptive names
Use snake_case for variables: homework_score, quiz_score
Name avg as average_score for clarity
Keep the logic the same, only change variable names
